6. Hiatus. The general attitude of Latin to hiatus is given by Cicero Orat. 150, ‘Quod quidem Latina lingua sic observat, nemo uttam msticus sit, qui vocales nolit coniungere.' Greek allowed hiatus, but ‘nobis ne si cupiamus quidem, distrahere¹ voces conceditur! Then, after quoting examples of hiatus from Naevius and Ennius, he concludes ‘hoc idem nostri saepius non tulissent’ Quintilian also (lx. 4. 33) disapproves ‘vocalium con- cursum, quod cum accidit, hiat et intersistit² et quasi laborat oratio’

In Plautus hiatus occurs between two words closely connected —a preposition and its noun, a pair of nouns, a noun and its verb, an adjective and its noun, δια, de ea, octo hominum, gratiam habeo, tuam amicam, eri imperia.

But hiatus is practically confined to cases when there is a pause in metre orin sensewhich atleast tunes down theharshness. Thus there may be hiatus at the caesura. Most frequently where hiatus occurs there is a pause in both sense and metre, and, even where these double pauses coincide, in an overwhelming number of cases there is no hiatus, e.g. when one speaker leavesa line uufmished and another takes it up hiatus is rare.

Hiatus most frequently accompanies breaks in sense when they are considerable, especially if there is achange of speakers.

Most frequently hiatus is met with in the case of mono- syllables with a long vowel (pro, de, dre.) or a short vowel if the word ends with m (nam, cum) in cases like quae ega, qui in, nam ego, ne ego, qui homo, di ament, cum Alcumena, quam ob rem, quiobviam.

Cases of hiatus are pretty frequent before homo, in nom.
